response:
Nikole Hannah-Jones is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who is known for her work on racial and economic inequality in the United States. She was born in Waterloo, Iowa in 1976 and grew up in the Midwest. She attended the University of Notre Dame and earned a degree in history and African American studies in 1998.

After graduating, Hannah-Jones began her career as a journalist, working for several newspapers across the country, including The Oregonian, The News & Observer in Raleigh, North Carolina, and The New York Times. She has written extensively on issues related to segregation, housing discrimination, and school resegregation.

In 2019, Hannah-Jones was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Commentary for her work on The 1619 Project, a special issue of The New York Times Magazine that explores the legacy of slavery in America. Hannah-Jones was the lead writer and conceived of the project, which has sparked a national conversation about the role of slavery in shaping American history.

Today, Hannah-Jones continues to write and speak about issues related to race and inequality. She is a MacArthur Fellow and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
